element_texts.text:
Pocket Diary 
for 
1863. 
CONTAINING 
A BLANK SPACE FOR EVERY DAY IN THE YEAR, 
RATES OF POSTAGE, 
CALENDAR, &C. 
NEW YORK: 
PUBLISHED ANNUALLY FOR THE TRADE. 
1863.

Corpl. Geo. M. Templeton 
Co D 149th Pa Vols
Bucktail Brigade
From Canonsburg 
Washington Co
Penna

THURSDAY, JANUARY 1, 1863
This was a great day in this city. In the forenoon 
all the distinguished military men in the city 
called in a body on Sec Stanton; at the head of the column 
was Gen Halleck. I recognized Gen H., Gens Hirst? 
unclear, Cadwalader, McDowell, Garfield &c 
In the afternoon I went to the Pres. reception. Had the 
pleasure of shaking hands with "Honest-Abe". He 
seemed in good spirits and looked well. Went to
unclear "Soldiers Free Library" & along with about 2000 
recd some apples & cakes sent by the ladies of Mass.
FRIDAY 2 
Nothing of interest happened today.
SATURDAY 3
Ditto

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 7, 1863.
Went to congress, Field of New J?
made a long speech on the "habeas
corpus" question. In the House the 
Bankrupt bill was discussed at
length.
THURSDAY 8
Went to Congress. Saulsbury of
Del made a discussion speech
on illegal arrests. The appropriation 
bill was up in the House. Met Jeff
Patton on his way to visit the army
of the Potomac. Harry's father came
FRIDAY 9
Harry recd a telegraphic dispatch. Went
to congress to find him. Some member of the 
House from Mo made a speech to which
Brigham of Ohio replyed in a very able & cutting
tone?. Saw the affair of the policeman and the 
soldier. helped the soldier.

SUNDAY, JANUARY 4, 1863.
Attended Dr Gurley's church in the
morning. As I went on guard at
1 o'clock I could not stay until the close
of the exercises. Went to 14th St. church in the
evening. The President met 200 or 300
contrabands while on his way from church and
welcomed them to freedom.
MONDAY 5
Commenced drilling by numbers
TUESDAY 6
Harry went to the Depot to meet
his father, whom he was expecting
to pay him a visit. He did
not come.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1863.
Went to Congress again today. 
Most of the time was spent on
eulogies on Senator Pierce of
Md.
WEDNESDAY 14
Went to Congress. Brigham of Ohio &
Wright of Pa made strong speeches
in reply to a peace speech of
Valandingham.
THURSDAY 15
Corporal Stewart & 8 men went
to Trinity church to attend a funeral.
The went to the Soldiers Home

SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1863.
Rained almost all day. 
SUNDAY 11
Attended Dr Gurly's. Dr Arley of 
Ct. one of the secs of the American 
Colonization Soc preached from Psalm
68 & 31. Not much sermon about it.
MONDAY 12
Went to Congress. Brigham used 
up the Secsh again on the Confiscation
act.

MONDAY, JANUARY 19, 1863.
Went to a Methodist Miss. Meeting. The orderly gave 20 doll. for our comp The Maj. gave $.100 in behalf of the officers, to make Col Stone a life member.
TUESDAY 20
Very wet weather
WEDNESDAY 21
Very muddy.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 16, 1863.
Very cold today.
SATURDAY 17
Still cold: Reading 'Casey's Tactics"
SUNDAY 18
Read 12 chaps of Math. while on guard from 1 am until 5 am. attended Dr Gurley Text Ex 19.10 & 11. Dr Baird & some other gentleman assisted at the sacrament. Lieut Slagle came back this morning bringing a letter from S.A & Templeton.

SUNDAY, JANUARY 25, 1863.
Attended Dr Gurly's church
Dr Baird preached a missionary
sermon
MONDAY 26
Lieut Dalgliesh reced a furlough
for 10 days. Went down town & 
got a picture taken in citizens
dress. An order came in the evening
for the "Commandant of 150th Reg Cdr of
15 & I? sts," to report his command of the 
Provost marshals office.
TUESDAY 27
Went to Congress. The bill for raising
negro regiments was before the House
laid over. In the Senate Garrett Davis
made a speech on the "Habeas corpus" question
This was the day Senator Saulsbury of Del 
created the trouble.
Raining

THURSDAY, JANUARY 22, 1863.
Was paid up to Nov 1st .
I recd $17.33 pay for 1 month and 10 days.
FRIDAY 23
Subscribed for the Chronicle. Went to Congress. Spoke to Gen Lane, he invited me to call & see him
SATURDAY 24
Reced first no of the Chronicle  Charlie & John Marks were put in the guard house for not having the pass dated.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 31, 1863.
Nothing of interest happened today
SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 1
Took sick suddenly about 1 AM with diarreah. Quite severe.
MONDAY 2
Still sick. Being on the sick list I had to go to the Dr who gave me some pills. Potts went home on furlough

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1863.
Corporal Stewart met with a sad accident. While choping wood for his stove his foot sliped & the axe fell on it, severing the great toe & the one next it, completely from the foot  Snowing & cold. Senate did not adjourn unclear 10 PM
THURSDAY 29
Went to Congress. The Bill for emancipation of slaves in Mo. was before the Senate. The Bill for raising negro troops was before the House. Heard speechs by Crittenden & Kelly. Just think of 2 Bills of such vital importance, & upon which hang the fate of the Union, being brought up in one day in both branches of Congress.
FRIDAY 30
Very muddy and slopy. The House did not adjourn its Wednesday's session until 5 A.M. of Thursday.  Saulsburg of Del apologized yesterday for the course he took in the Senate on Wednesday.  They are not going to push the motion for his expulsion at present.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1863.
All the snow is gone, unclear Nesbit went home on furlough today.
SATURDAY 7
Corporal Calohan came back today.
SUNDAY 8
Went to Dr Gurly's church in the evening.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1863.
Went to Congress. McDougall of California was making a speech in the Senate on the French-Mexico question. The bill for the great western canal was before the House. Also the Submarine cable bill.
WEDNESDAY 4
Lieut. Dalgleish returned, but did not bring any thing for me  About 3 inches of snow on the ground
THURSDAY 5
I have heard that they have a company of 100 negroes raised in the city to be ready when the bill for arming them passed the Senate. Cant say whether it is so, or not.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1863.
Had a rumor in camp that we would go at one o'clock. Took a box to the Express Office to be sent home. Recd four letters today.  One from Margarette saying that she had sent a box. H.F. Stewart got his discharge today.
FRIDAY 13
Bought 28 cap covers for the men, at $3.00 per dozen. Went to see Gen Moorhead  He did not give me any encouragement.
SATURDAY 14
Making preparations to march in the morning at 6 o'clock  Corp. Stewart received his discharge a day or two ago

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1863.
Having heard that the Reserves had come up the river I went down to the wharf and learned that they had landed at Alexandria. Went to the Provost Marshals office and got a pass to go over.
TUESDAY 10
Started early in the morning to Alexandria & found all the boys. Saw Capt Craig who is on detached duty in the Straglers camp. When I came back to camp found the regt had marching orders
WEDNESDAY 11
Had inspection at sunrise and began to pack up for to be ready to go. Went & spoke to Judge Kelley  David Reed called a few minutes to see me.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1863.
Rained all day & night. 25 of our Co & about 200 of the regt went out on picket at 7 o'clock this morning. Commenced building a hut, and had to carry logs to build one for the Captain.
THURSDAY 19
Finished our hut so that we could sleep in it at night. I went over yesterday to the 56 Pa to see Lieut. Dave Cunningham. D.W. Moss came from Wash. and came to camp today. We took Stoddard & Swiford into our mess
FRIDAY 20
The boys came in from picket pretty well done out. Built a chimney in our hut, and stopped up the cracks.
Corporal Wm. Templeton returned from being home on furlough.

SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1863
Marched down to the 7th St landing and our regt & the 150 went on board the Lousiania & left the wharf at 3 P.M. The scenery on the river is not very interesting. The boat tied up at the mouth of Regina Creek about unclear - dawn?
MONDAY 16
At daylight we hove anchor and steamed down to the mouth of Potomac creek, where we changed our boat for one of lighter draught and went up to  Belle Plain landing, where we landed and after unloading marched about 2 miles and camped. Had my tent up first of any in camp.
TUESDAY 17
When I awoke found 4 or 5 inches of snow on the ground & still snowing, which it continued to do all day, turning to rain in the evening. This was one of the most dreary days I ever saw. We did not bring tents along, only unclear blankets.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1863.
Returned to camp. Our line captured an old grey haired man, who shot at our pickets and tryed to pass. The following were detached yesterday. Corp Wm Templeton, Priceland?, Mensor?, Pettit, Meares, Rogers. They went some for ambulance drivers & some into the artillery.
WEDNESDAY  25
General inspection today, by the inspecting officer (a capt in the 150th Pa.). David Philips was promoted to be corporal in Stewarts place. (on the 14th) Lieut. Slagle has been detailed as Judge Advocate of the division
THURSDAY 26
Rained almost all day. Leith & Morrison & Gordon are detached today.
Wrote to Mame
Lieut Dalgleish has been detailed as aid to Gen. Stone.

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1863.
Finished our hut, made bunks making it very comfortable. We made our bunks out of poles and then put pine brush on them. Had co drill from 8 to 10 AM and dress parade in the evening.
SUNDAY 22
Snowed most of the night and all day. Was wakened up before daylight to go on picket. 13 men; 3 corps & a sargent of our co. Went out with 40 rounds of cartridges and 2 days rations, to the line 1 1/2 miles from the Rapihannoc. Being in the advance only a capt & 2 pioneers before me It was hard marching
MONDAY 23
This picket business is hard work, but keep in the best of spirits.  We are near a secesh home and have been using his rails for making fire. This morning the guard at his home threatened to shoot us if we did not quit taking them, I am out at a post with 3 men.

MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1863.
Was detailed on picket. Had post
as 13. This was a fine warm day
I was on from 11 PM to 5 AM
of Tuesday. About 1 1/2 am it commenced raining & rained until morning.
TUESDAY 3
The sky was quite clear when I 
awoke. Clouded up about 1 PM & for
an hour we had some rain. Went
on at 5 PM. Came off at 11 PM.
Bond was detailed.
WEDNESDAY 4
Went to camp and found a spud
from Kelley for me.
They have been drilling 8 hours
a day since we went out. 
Went to Div. Headqts to see about
my box: could not find it.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 27,1863
Drilled from 8 to 11. In the
afternoon Col Stone drilled the non-commissioned officers
in the skirmish drill.
SATURDAY 28
Were mustered in by Col
Dwight. Had to take Dobson 
into the mess.
SUNDAY, MARCH 1
Had a grand review of Brigade by Ben Stone + staff, accompanied by Mrs. Stone. We
marched past in quick time in colli.. & then in double quick.  It was 
quite a fine day in the afternoon.
Got a letter from Father.

SUNDAY, MARCH 8, 1863.
They sent out one days rations
with instructions to stay one day
longer. Spent a very quiet 
Sabbath. Finished reading
Mathew through
MONDAY 9
Were relieved & came to camp 
found letters from Father & Jim Black.
The Repository & a package of spuds 
from Judge Kelley.
TUESDAY 10
Did not feel well. Staid in bed
almost all day. Got wet one night while on picket
which started a fever on me.

THURSDAY, MARCH 5, 1863.
Received a note from Hon. Wm. 
D. Kelley saying that he had 
filed my application at the war 
department, with a strong 
recommendation from him.
Drilled 8 hours today. 
FRIDAY 6
Volunteered to go on picket in 
place of Jones, so he was detailed
as clerk to Judge advocate.
Wrote to Margaretta.
Dobson detailed as a guard
at Doubleday's headquarters.
SATURDAY 7
Wrote to Father enclosing documents. The outer line of 
pickets fired of their guns about
half past 10 PM. The reserves 
were awakened & formed in
line. I had just come off my post
& gone to bed.

SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1863. 
Went to the hospital today.
SUNDAY 15
Dr. decided that I had the typhoid fever.
MONDAY 16
Resolved that if I get home safe after the war that I will by the help of God live a Christian life.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1863. 
Still worse.
THURSDAY 12
Ditto
FRIDAY13
Ditto

SUNDAY, MARCH 29, 1863.
J. B. Momyer?, Samuel Racek
and Wm. Menser received
their discharges today.
MONDAY 30
TUESDAY 31

TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1863.
Able to sit up a little.
Saw in the "Chronicle" that my 
box was at Washington. Sent
for it.
WEDNESDAY 8
A review near Falmouth 
of 4 corps (70,000 men) Pres 
Lincoln and family were 
present; He says he never saw
the army in such a fine
condition.
THURSDAY 9
Our corps was reviewed by Gen Hooker and Pres Lincoln. The President's family was present. The army of the Potomac is far from demoralized.

SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1863.
SUNDAY 5
Quite a snow storm last night.
MONDAY 6
Getting quite an appetite 
and consequently getting
better.

MONDAY, APRIL 13, 1863.
Applyed for a furlough. Dr Hunter
was writing a certificate when Dr. Humphry came in & said
that there were no furloughs 
granted. He took down the names of
those who were to be sent to Washington.
TUESDAY 14
10,000 cavalry moved at daylight
Lieut Slagle applyed to Dr. Humphry 
to have me sent to Washington. 
Got my descriptive list.
Dr. Humphry could not send me to W.
the div, hosp. was broken up and one man
brought over here to be sent to Argonia Creek.
WEDNESDAY 15
The regt. was to move at daylight, but a storm of rain commenced in the night which put a stop to the move.  Read a letter from Adam's agent enclosing the dollar saying they found the box paid for, also one from E J. & A. S Thompson

FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1863.
Still better. All regiments
were mustered to see how 
many conscripts it will take
to fill up the regts.
SATURDAY 11
Still better.
SUNDAY 12
Read the United Presbyterians and my
testaments. Recd Margaretta's box after being 2
or 3 days on the way. The
things were all good except a chicken

SUNDAY APRIL 19, 1863.
A beautiful day. Received orders to be ready to go in the ambulances at 10 o'clock next day.
MONDAY 20
Recd. orders later in the evening to be ready at 4 a.m. today. went to Belle Plain & went on board of a transport & went to Windmill pt. hosp.  Commenced raining soon after arriving. Stood in the rain got in a Sibley tent & in the evening Dr put me in ward.
TUESDAY 21
I find our Dr (Reamer) is very strict; He keeps me in the ward pretty closely, however I go out to get my meals. Those put down to go to Wash from their regts. went today

THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1863.
Rained all day.  Most miserable to stay in the hospital all day.
FRIDAY 17
Cleared up.
SATURDAY 18 
The regt. was paid 4 mo pay ($52) this morning  The 143 was paid in the afternoon.  All of our regt relieved the 150th on picket so that they may be paid off.

SATURDAY APRIL 25,1863.
They don't get their bread for dinner until about 3 o'clock. The convalescents commenced getting their rations and cooking for themselves.
SUNDAY 26
Read some tracts & my testament. The Dr alowed me to get out of bed today for the first time for some days.
MONDAY 27
This was a beautiful day, but I was not permitted to enjoy it out of doors. Wrote to the Co for my mail. Park Hickman died today at 8 a.m. this makes 4 that have died of our comp.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1863
The Dr put all the patients in bed and would not allow them to sit up any. I have my full rations brought to me. Our division came back from a scout of three days
THURSDAY 23
As my bed has no tick on it makes me tired to lie in bed all day. The division was ordered out on a scout this morning.
FRIDAY 24
Lieutenant D.W Dull of Co H 142nd P.T. from Fayette Co lies next bed to me. He & I try to amuse ourselves as well as we can

FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1863.
Quite heavy firing on the front. The Dr put me on full rations again. Went down to the Forage Landing to the sutlers.
SATURDAY 2
Walked down to the sutlers. Very heavy firing this morning. Any amount of rumors are going, but none that you can put any confidence in.
SUNDAY 3
Very heavy firing this morning from daylight until 9 o'clock. Continuing almost all day very heavy in the evening.

TUESDAY, APRIL 28, 1863.
Wrote to Eliza Jane. Miss Dix visited our hospital today; she is a very fine lady. 84 men from our Division came in today. Allison & Barckley came from our Co.
WEDNESDAY 29
Wrote a letter of 11 pages to Samuel?
The report is that Hooker has crossed the Rappihannock at 3 places. The heavy artillery firing this morning unclear indicate that something was going on.
THURSDAY 30
This is the President's Fast day. There is not much firing going on at the front 
The Dr allowed me to walk out. Q'Master Cushman of the 135 Pa lies on on side of me

THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1863.
Rumors are afloat of the retirement of the army of the Potomac on to this side of the river again.
FRIDAY 8
Nothing new today.  A man came from Wash. to get the Q. Master of the 135 who lies beside me. He went to Falmouth to see some Dr in reference to it.
SATURDAY 9
Went to Hamptons Battery to see Halsey Williams; he was absent at the time so I did not see him. Knapp's Battery is lying a mile further on.

MONDAY, MAY 4, 1863.
Heavy firing today. Some more convalescents sent to their regiments.
TUESDAY 5
Firing continued today. Quite a number of letters came here for the boys that had gone to their regiments. Forwarded them to the regts
WEDNESDAY 6
A heavy rain storm came on last evening & continued almost all day. There were a few shots fired this morning. This will make an eight day fight.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1863.
Went to see Dr Ward in command of Corps hospital, in reference to geting the position of Corps Postmaster as soon as the time of the present incumbent expires.  He gave me some encouragement.
THURSDAY 14
Went down to the river & fished a while, but did not catch any
Had a rain storm this evening
Wrote to Lieut Slagle for a recommendation.
FRIDAY 15
Geary & Nicholl came to see me again: they expect to move to Stafford tomorrow
It is quite cold today
The 135 Pa of our Div went home today

SUNDAY, MAY 10, 1863.
Read some in my Testament. A very warm day.  They have a good regulation in this hospital: i.e. to have all wash or have their feet washed every sabbath.
MONDAY 11
Sent a note to Geary telling where I am. Got a pass and went down to Aquia Creek Landing. Happened to meet Wm unclear who used to live in C. & go to school with me. A great many N.Y. 2 years & 9 mos men were going home
TUESDAY 12
Geary & Nicholl of his battery came over to see me. They look natural They moved the hospital up to the hill on the bank of the Potomac about 100 yds distant. I worked a good deal and was very tired again night. Recd my first letter since I came here

TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1863.
Not any better. Have an attack of the diarrhoea
WEDNESDAY 20
Nothing new
THURSDAY 21
One of the Christian Commission (Rev. Stephenson of Connellsville) called when he found I was from Canonsburg he stayed & talked a while. He said he had married Silvia Hunt to Mr. Hammill. Also? that Prof. Fraser had first joined his church.

SATURDAY, MAY 16, 1863.
Those of the 135 Pa who were in this hospital went home this evening.  Dr Reames gave me a recommendation, which I gave to Dr Ward who said it was all right.
SUNDAY 17
Nothing of interest happened today
MONDAY 18
Did not feel so well today.  Recd 3 letters: one from Father & Mother one from Sarah Ann & Templeton Ra? & one from Nicholls
Dr put me on half rations

MONDAY, MAY 25, 1863.
Harrington Co C 150 Pa died in our ward of congestion of the lungs 
A boat-load of contrabands came up from Belle Plain. They were captured during some of our cavalry raids.
TUESDAY 26
Craigle of Co C 143 Pa died in our ward today.
WEDNESDAY 27
Went about a mile to a sutler and bought about 4 lbs of butter. Only $2.00. Half of it is for Sergt Lesme.

FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1863.
Nothing new
SATURDAY 23
Dr Humphrey Div. surgeon examined the patients: sent some to Invalids Corps: some to their regiments; and others to stay here
SUNDAY 24
Read in my testament Received letters from Home & M. also a Hamper?

SUNDAY, MAY 31, 1863.
Went to the Christian Commission Chaple and heard the best sermon I have heard since I left home.
MONDAY, JUNE 1
Forb. Morrow's father came to see him. Forb is quite deranged today. I went over to the Post Office when the mail came in: dont like the arrangements for distributing, too much chance for fraud.
TUESDAY 2
Received a letter from Father and mother enclosing a photograph of Samuel. I think it is a good picture.

THURSDAY, MAY 28, 1863.
About 75 sick came to our division
Forb.? Morrow came from our comp.
FRIDAY 29
Was ordered to report at the 1st div. to get acquainted with the Post Master. Dr Ward came to me and wanted me to be his clerk. I respectfully declined, and on his urging I told him I would think about it.
SATURDAY 30
Nothing new

SATURDAY, JUNE 6, 1863.
Went into the Potomac for the first time; the waves being pretty high it was very pleasant. Heard that Knap's Battery was lying near.
SUNDAY 7
Went over to see if I could find Ed. Geary: found the Battery had been lying within 1/2 mile of us for 2 weeks. On my way over had a mess of wild strawberries. Attended church in the afternoon
MONDAY 8
Forb. Morrow. died this morning at 6 o'clock. This makes the 5th of our company who have died since we came out;

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1863.
Morrow is worse today. Mr Morrow told me that our co had been detailed as Provost general for the Division.
THURSDAY 4
75 or 100 sick came to our division. I went to the convalescent camp and Sergt Leslie? and I went into a wall tent along with Corp. Lent & another man of Co R
FRIDAY 5
Henry and I went to the woods and cut poles and made a bunk

FRIDAY, JUNE 12, 1863.
Nobles of Co A died today.
SATURDAY 13
Went down to Aquia and was introduced to the Post Master as the next P.M. Dr Ward received orders about work to vacate inside of 48 hours. Commenced packing up & tearing down tents.
SUNDAY 14
Dr Ward said there was no use in going down for the mail. Very busy and about 3 o'clock an orderly came into camp and said we must be on the boat in 5 minutes. Went up to wash and arrived at Soldier's Retreat at 11 P.M.

TUESDAY, JUNE 9, 1863.
Burried Morrow at 6 PM along with another of our division and one fo the 1st div. Six of us Bucktails acted as pall bearers. Went strawberrying, got quite a number but they were very small.
WEDNESDAY 10
The Post Master wanted me to go over this evening.
Dr Reamer gave us permission to up in the cherry tree. Got some splendid ones.
THURSDAY 11
Went over to P.O. to help them to move the tent to another place. Worked pretty hard. Went down to Aquia with the Post Master. Saw Ed Geary & his Capt. (Charlie Atwell) and a P K Y Lieut.

THURSDAY, JUNE 18, 1863.
Left Soldier's Retreat at 9 A.M. marched up the Avenue to Georgetown, where we took canal boats for Point of Rocks, Md. In the evening a hail storm came up, hail stones as large as hen eggs fell in abundance. I tell you they hurt. Stoped at dark and most of us slept on the boats. McEwen & I slept on top of the boat it raining all the time.
FRIDAY 19
Started off in the morning and arrived at the Monocacy in the evening 5 miles from Pt of Rocks. The guard stoped us as the rebs. were 2 miles above. Went up on the top of a hill and laid out for the night. Oh how it did rain! The water ran down my neck in a stream
SATURDAY 20
Got up early and with our wet blankets started for Edward's Ferry (11 miles) back on the way we had come. This we had to march, we arrived about 2 P.M. camped between the canal & the Potomac. Pitched a tent and drew 2 days rations.

MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1863.
Staid at the retreat all day. Express my overcoat, blanket &c home, also H.H. Leskin's overcoat to his father. Got my picture taken & sent it to Mary. Washington looks like home.
TUESDAY 16
About 8 A.M started on the cars went to Alex and from there to the Convalescent camp. The camp is a very comfortable place having nice clean barracks and pretty good grub. Some of the boys went over to Camp Distribution at 11 P.M.
WEDNESDAY 17
Went to officer in command of Pa troops, wanting to go to my regt. He said I could not go. Went to Headquarters asked the Adjt to let me go to my regt. he said "that's the way Corpl that I like to see fellows do" Went to Camp Distribution. Left with about 50 at 2 PM for Regts. Took boat at Alexandria for Soldier's Retreat Washington.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1863.
Lay around almost all day. Went on duty and took a prisoner to Court Marshall.
Received letters from Father Mother and Miss Morrow, at Division P.O
THURSDAY 25
Received marching orders and about 9 A.M. started, marched to the Potomac and crossed the pontoons to Edwards Ferry. Went through Poolesville & camped at Barnsville Md. about 17 miles Rained almost all the time, arrived at 9 PM
FRIDAY 26
Rained all day. Started about 7 AM. Marched through a fine country. The wheat is splendid and the people live well. Crossed the Monocacy and passed through Adams Town about 4 miles and camped. Had a pleasant place to sleep in a hay mow?. 15 or 16 miles today.

SUNDAY, JUNE 21, 1863.
The engineers laid a pontoon bridge of 63 boats last night: commenced cannonading early this morning and kept it up all day. They say our men drove the Rebs. The 12th Corps are on the other side & the men of that corps with us went over this morning.
MONDAY 22
Had a good nights sleep under dry blanket. The men of the 11th Corps went across this morning. About 3 P.M received marching orders, crossed on the pontoon bridge & marched 5 or 6 miles to Leesburgh and camped about 1/2 mile from there. Passed the graves of 3 deserters of the 12th corps who had been shot.
TUESDAY 23
Got up early and marched down the Leesburgh & Alexandria railroad and pike to Gen Reynold's headquarters 10 or 11 miles and from there a mile to Gen Doubleday's. Went off withJim? & Whit Moss to get boards to floor our tent. Recd a letter from Sarah Ann

TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1863.
Marched 4 miles and stoped in a farm. Had a good nights sleep. The Co. was mustered in for pay being the last day of the month specified
large writing Gettysburg end large writing
WEDNESDAY, JULY 1
Started early and marched very rapidly until about 1 P.M. when we came to Gettysburg where a fight was going on between the rebs & 1st div. Our div. was in until nearly dark without relief. Our regt lost 333 out of 454 that went in all officers but 6 & the colors. Our Co. stood against a whole brigade until they were within 25 yds, I was nearly captured, got on a cavalry horse whose rider was killed.
THURSDAY 2
The co returned to the regt. We retired about a mile & a half & laid in the front line all night. Gen Rowley told Gen. Doubleday how the Provost guard behaved & the N.Y Tribune reporter took notice of it. A very hard fight today. Our regt. went in in the evening and took? off some cannons that were left in the field. Were on picket all night. Lost 2 men out of co. C while taking the cannon off.

MONDAY, JULY 6, 1863.
Went back as Provost guard. 
Left early for Emmetsburg arrived about noon and went into camp nearby 
Camped in a clover field. The rebs (2000 cavalry) went through here yesterday morning. The rebs had their right flank well fortified agains attack.
TUESDAY 7
Started early and stoped for dinner 2 miles this side of Katocktin unclear turned off the Fredrick road & crossed the Katocktin mountain. The steepest road I ever saw. Camped on this side of the slope. We in a barn. Rained all night.
WEDNESDAY 8
Started very early, and came through Middletown & camped on the Hagerstown pike in a barn. Rained all morning was wet through. About 3 P.M. the rain having ceased we marched through south mountain Pass & camped on the western slope. Firing in front this evening.

FRIDAY, JULY 3, 1863.
Were shelled very hard before being relieved from picket. This was the hardest fight during the war. The artillery fire during the afternoon was tremendous. Old soldiers say they never heard the like. White was wounded in the head with a piece of shell. We laid in line all day & hugged the ground pretty close.
SATURDAY 4
This is the glorious 4th of July, an is just in time to celebrate a great victory. The rebs are retreating & we are burying the dead. We have been on short rations for the last day or two on account of the trains being so far back.
SUNDAY 5
Got some rations and laid around all day, raining most of the time. The field of battle presents a horrible appearance, a great many are unclear unclear & horses & broken caisons &c lie around in great numbers.

SUNDAY, JULY 12,1863.
Laid in camp until about 2 PM. Marched through Funkstown and crossed Antietam creek on the Hagerstown pike bridge. While going into position we run into the pickets and drove them back. Took position in the rear of the Div
MONDAY 13
Laid in position all day. Some skirmishing going on. The Rebs fired 2 or 3 cannon which were answered. Our men brot in a squad of 100 prisoners. Antietam creek is about a half mile in our rear.
TUESDAY 14
Marched to within 2 miles of Williamsport and camped for the night.

THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1863.
Laid here all day and drew rations the first thing we have had to eat for two days. Could not get shoes My feet are worn and bleeding. Wm. Smith died at Frederick City Hospital today
FRIDAY 10
Marched out the Hagerstown pike about 5 miles and camped in a piece of woods, where rebs had lain yesterday. The cavalry have been doing some fighting, & capturing prisoners.
SATURDAY 11
About 9 A.M. changed position, 3 Division taking position on extreme left of line. Gen Kenley's brigade of Md troops joined our Div. Gen Kenley, outranking Rowley, took command of Div.

SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1863.
Started early, crossed the river at Berlin? on the pontoons and marched about 10 miles and camped about dinner time near the village of Waterford.
SUNDAY 19
Marched at daylight and camped about dinner time near Hamilton. There were plenty of the finest dewberries I ever saw and we almost unclear on them. This is a good country: there a good many Quakers living in this neighbourhood,
MONDAY 20
Laid in one of the finest pieces of woods all day and had a great time eating & cooking berries. Our quartermasters are beginning to confiscate horses, cattle &c.

page torn, left side of torn page text from earlier page of July 9 to 11 
[[right side of torn page, ie. partial text:]
WEDNESDAY, JULY 15, 1863.
in the morning & 
hardest day move?
Near a small village? 
like Bucketsville 
THURSDAY 16
unclear
and? here.
FRIDAY  17
day. Had a unclear
last. Jim Black
unclear

FRIDAY, JULY 24, 1863.
Laid in camp all day. They are repairing the railroad to this place. Still out of rations. Our artillery are taking all the horses & the butchers all the cattle they can find. This is a very aristocratic town.
SATURDAY 25
Marched in the morning & camped about noon at Warrenton Junction. An awfull hot day, got rations in the evening for 5 days. This is a very poor place to camp, no shade a water is very hard to get and poor at that, Cars come fr Wash
SUNDAY 26
Laid in camp all day, awful hot. Received a mail, got a letter from home. The chaplain of the 4th MD had divine service. Being on guard I could not go.

TUESDAY, JULY 21, 1863.
Marched early, but moved very slow and did not get into camp at Middleburg, a very strong secesh town until after dark. There are some reb wounded here and hundreds have been buried in the cemetry. Knocked down pig, but it got up & ran near to where a guard was. I could not get it.
WEDNESDAY 22
Laid in camp until 5 P.M. The infantry marched among the wagons, causing us to move very slow, halted at White Plains at 2 A.M. & laid down until morning when we foudn HdQrs, but started again at 9 o'clock AM of Thursday. This night march was very hard.
THURSDAY 23
As I said we started at 9 AM and arrived at Warrenton about dinner time. This is a strong secesh town. There are some reb. wounded here unclear. Heard cannon in the directions of Sperryville got out of rations, plenty of dewberries, however.

THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1863.
Laid in camp all the time. Our division is guarding the R.R. between the Junction & Rapihannock Station.
FRIDAY 31
Still in camp.
SATURDAY, AUGUST 1
Moved Hd Qrs to Bealton Station 6 miles towards Culpepper. Fixed up our camp better than we ever did before, with boards &c.

MONDAY, JULY 27, 1863.
Laid in camp. While at Gettysburg just after we came out of the first day's fight, a boy by the name of Albert Cupp from Lyerming Co. came to our Co. He did not know who recruited him, nor did he know any in the reg, but only knew he was recruited for Co. D 149 P unclear on the 3rd day he was struck with piece of shell, and thought he was hurt & wanted some one to carry him off. He found he was not even bruised and made tracks to the rear Was detailed with 4 men to go to depot to unload? express boxes. mine was among the lot. I had to look out for the interests of our div.
WEDNESDAY 29
Was ordered to report again at Corp Hd Qrs with 4 men to unload boxes?. Went to depot, but no boxes came. The officer in command of depot was going to buck & gag me for taking hard tack on a box. I let him know that when I was unclear and there were any tack to get I was going to have

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1863.
Nothing og interest today. 
Orderly Snodgrass has put on first Lts straps. He is very foolish and green for there is no vacancy, & the boys make fun of him.
THURSDAY 6
The Capt having received information that Cupp our recruit had been recruited for the 49th P.V., he sent him along with me to the Corps head Qrs. to Capt Taylor. Corps Provost Marshal.
FRIDAY 7
Barton took the keg of gin out of the Capt tent while they were taking an afternoons nap and after they had emptied it, set it back in its place. Dick & Whit. took too much, and got pretty funny; I took them out of the Capts sight.

SUNDAY< AUGUST 2, 1863.
Of course we had to march today. We on the way almost every day & camped 4 miles further toward Culpepper. Crossed the Rappihannock at R Station and in the evening crossed back again. This was the hotest day yet.
MONDAY 3
In camp about a quarter of a mile from the river, a splendid spring a mile from camp
TUESDAY 4
The Rappihannock is not as wide as Chartiers Creek, but is from 4 to 10 feet deep and very swift.
It makes a splendid place to see?. There was heavy cannonading across the river we were drawn up in line and expected to cross; could see the shells burst

TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1863.
I went over to see the Reserves about a mile from here. All the boys seem well. I hear a good many things that are going on at home, when I see those fellows.
WEDNESDAY 12
Nothing of interest happened today
THURSDAY 13
It rained quite heavily this morning before daylight

SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1863.
We had inspection of arms today at 2 P.M. by Capt Glenn.
Frank Dorrington 3d. Corporal has been promoted to 3d. sergt. & those below have been raised one grade, except Philips, who gains two jumping Jones?
SUNDAY 9
A very quiet Sabbath and it is a wonder we did not move. Had inspection at 9 o'clock by Capt Cowdry, of the staff.
MONDAY 10
I went to the river and washed my pants and shirt, puting them on as soon as washed. If one would do this at home they would think it necessary that they should get sick. Not so out here.

MONDAY, AUGUST 17, 1863.
We forage a good deal now, geting beans, corn, some peaches & pears. Jim Black & Culver came over & took dinner with me.
TUESDAY 18
Got orders to pack up and be ready to move camp at 4 P.M. Moved about a mile stoping on a ridge, where there are no trees or shade, but an excelent well of water.
WEDNESDAY 19
This evening we had an alarm of the rebs coming. Our div. left tents & drew up in line of battle along the river. The reserves were out also. It turned out to be our cavalry coming in, and no rebs at all.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 14, 1863.
Nothing of interest happened today.
SATURDAY 15
Ditto
SUNDAY 16
Allison and Neil came back today they have not been exchanged, but they are not going to recognise the parole. Potts came back while we were at Warrenton Junction. Calohan and Kerr were at home when the others left.

SUNDAY, AUGUST 23, 1863.
Heard Dr McClassen preach this evening.
MONDAY 24
Went out foraging: was gathering beans when the guard and owner came and wanted us to either leave the beans or pay 25 cts per qt. Couldn't see it. Went another place & got some corn.
TUESDAY 25
The weather for the last few weeks has been very warm.

THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1863.
Nothing of interest today
FRIDAY 21
Went over to the Reserves in the evening and heard their Chaplain Dr McClason make a few remarks on "Manliness"
SATURDAY 22
Ben Kerr came back today today, none of our prisoners are now away unclear Calohan, Ustie Rotherick came from Frederick City hospital

SATURDAY, AUGUST 29, 1863.
The 5 deserters were executed today in the presence of the 5th corps. We have about 20 of our Div under guard for desertion.
SUNDAY 30
The weather has been very cool during the past week.
MONDAY 31
Were mustered in today. Gen Kenley reviewed his Division: they are talking of puting the 1st & 2nd brigades together under the command of Gen Rowley.

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 26, 1863.
Quite a change in the atmosphere This was the day appointed for the execution of 5 deserters in the 5th Corps, but it was defered until Saturday.
THURSDAY 27
Nick, myself & three others went out about midnight about three miles & took a box of beer & got to camp at daylight with about 50 lbs of honey.
FRIDAY 28
This was the day fixed for the presentation of a sword to Gen Meade by the Penn Reserves. I was over & saw the ceremony & heard speech made by Meade, Crawford, Gov. Curtin, Forney & others. About 9 PM the 1st brigade of the Reserves made a raid on a sutler of our Div We went down on the double quick & charging made them skedaddle

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1863.
Nothing new.
SATURDAY 5
Wrote some for Slagle.
SUNDAY 6
Went over to the Reserves and heard Rev. Torrance of the 11th preach and after he was through heard a part of of a sermon by Dr McClassen of the 10th Regiment.

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1863.
Did some writing for Lt Slagle, copying the records of Court Marshals. I wrote 10 pages of fools cap.
WEDNESDAY 2
The inspector Genl. of 1st Corps inspected our unclear blankets, shelter tents, canteens haversacks &c. He condemned all the blankets and haversacks. Wrote about 20 pages for Lt Slagle, today. He compliments me on my writing.
THURSDAY 3
Wrote some for Slagle tonight.

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1863.
Nothing of importance.
FRIDAY 11
Reported to Capt Osborne
SATURDAY 12
Went to Bealeton for a load of rails: fixed up the tent tenting with Jones & 2 others & messing with 9 others. 2d. Corps camped nears us tonight I went to see the C. comp. saw all

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1863.
Wrote about 20 pages for Slagle. They issue out a ration of cornmeal to us. It was fun to see the boys baking cakes and making much.
TUESDAY 8
Went over to see John Rodgers Co C 9 Regt Reserves
WEDNESDAY 9
Was detailed as clerk to Captain Osborne Asst Inspector Genl at Brigade Headquarters

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1863.
Still in camp at the same place.
95 conscripts came for our regiment today: they come from Carlisle and seem to be a good class of men.
WEDNESDAY 23
The women who live around here are very bitter against us. One of them said , She guessed there did not all that went to Slaughter Mountain return again.
THURSDAY 24
Received orders about 12 o'clock to strike tents and march immediately. Marched towards the Rapinn. 5 or 6 miles taking the place of the 12th Corps, who went somewhere else. Genl. Kenley was put under arrest just before starting.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1863.
The brigade received 4 Mo pay today i.e. the 149 & 150th Reg I received 6 month's
The 143d. came up in the evening. They have 230 conscri? & are going to get some 250 more.
SUNDAY 20
Was very busy attending inspection of 143 Regt. and making out reports.
Our chaplain preached to our Company: but I was unable to attend.
MONDAY 21
Nothing new today
Sent $10.00 home by mail and $50.00 by express.

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1863.
We have Hd Qrs near a negro house. The occupant is very intelligent for a darkie? says sugar sold for 3 & 4 dollars per lb.
He is making preparations to move north. I saw a regular Southener dark ie dance in the house to night
TUESDAY 29
The 1st. & 2d. Divs moved camp early this morning, we did not move until 9 AM, & then went only a mile or two. I think we are making a show of troops to make the Rebs think we are stronger than we are
WEDNESDAY 30
Very busy today making out a long report I think we will all move out of this soon and perhaps try Richmond in some other quarter.

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1863.
Attended the execution of Chas? Williams Co D 4th Md Vols. He deserted about a year ago and came out as a substitute? 7 or 8 times. The Div. was formed? on 3 sides of a squar: a detail of the [[Md}} Brigade shot him.
SATURDAY 26
It is astonishing how many of the soldiers are confirmed gamblers. Lt. Dalgleish had some arrested & sent to their Col., but I dont think he punished them.
SUNDAY 27
While eating dinner received marching orders, moved 2 miles and are now within shelling distance of the Rebs. although the pickets fire there is no cannon fired. The pickets were very busy firing this morning.

SUNDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1863.
Attended church this evening at the 150th. I went up to the 4th Md Vols to heard a sermon from their chaplain. Just as he was commencing to preach, the rebs commenced to shell & as we did not know what caused it the Div. was put under arms & preaching adjourned. The rebs were shelling a forage wagon.
MONDAY 5
Nothing new, except the 6th Corps passed us going to relieve the 2d. Corps. Received a letter from home stating that Samuel had arrived at home.
TUESDAY 6
Went out a day or two ago with 5 pioneers & cut a bee tree getting about 150lbs of honey.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1863.
Very busy making out reports. Nicholls reced. yesterday papers authorising him to go and be examined for entrance into the Signal Corps. Col Dwight was very angry, because he got away without his consent.
FRIDAY 2
Rained all night & today. I saw a deserter out of the 2d. Div. shot this afternoon, a priest attended him. Very busy.
SATURDAY 3
The 143d. regiment received 140 conscripts today. These men seem to be a good class of men. I am looking for a letter from home but at 8 PM no mail has arrived.

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1863.
Were ordered out at 1A.M. & started for Morton's Ford expecting to cross the Rapidan. but as most of the Rebs. had evacuated the place we went into camp until dark when we marched to our day? camp near Stevensburg arriving at 11 P.M. These marches were very hard on us. You could see men stumbling into the mud &c.
SUNDAY 11
Were wakened up at 2 A.M. & marched at unclear but as soon as our Div. had got in line the order was countermanded & we laid down in the road & started at 11 A.M. Marched fast & crossed the Rappahannock on the Pontoons at Kellys ford on the double quick. Took position supporting batteries on this side. Rebs followed on our rear & fired a few shells: There was quite a skirmish up the river on our right
MONDAY 12
Laid all day the Rebs did not come in sight but there was quite a skirmish unclear about Rapphannock bridge. The regt. had another chase after some pigs.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1863.
Nothing new except Col Stone came back to see his commands; he is on crutches yet.
THURSDAY 8
Ditto. Except Col Stone rode in an ambulance along the 149th this morning & each company saluted him with 3 cheers. An officer riding along asked what it meant: he turned out to be Dr Geo Ramsay.
FRIDAY 9
Got a horse from Capt Osborne & went to the 2d. Corps. found them 1 mile on the other side of Culpepper. Saw Stewart? & got my shirt. Saw all of Fraser's Cr? Culpepper is a "right Smart" town.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1863.
Marched at daylight & came back to the forts. There is no cannonading today: the Rebs dont seem to be coming closer. Rained all evening. I got very wet & could not sleep so sat by the fire all night.
SATURDAY 17
Cleared up & was a fine day & saw Co. D of 10th Reserves the other day, Murray McNary came to see me.
SUNDAY 18
All quiet along the lines: our Corps is in front now. Were wakened up at daylight but did not move. Moved Hd Qrs a few rds. Had inspection in 149th & 150th Regts. Medical wagon & ambulance came up this evening.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1863.
Received marching orders and marched at 2 A.M. arrived at Warrenton Junction again 9 o'clock; rested 3 hours; as it depends on our corps to reach Bull? Run & Centerville before the Rebs, start again & stoped at Bristow Station at dark having marched 28 miles.
WEDNESDAY 14
Started at daylight & hurried along having skirmishers out in front & both flanks & arrived at Centerville again 2 PM? Went into camp and about an hour after there was heavy cannonading a few miles out & we were taken into the forts. The 2d. & 5th. Corps were engaged & captured a battery & 700 rebs.
THURSDAY 15
Broke camp about dinner time marching (our Div) 2 1/2 miles in a hurry towards Chantilly, in a few minutes after getting position firing commenced on the left coming closer, we expected to be in a fight in a few minutes, but it became more distant & we remained on picket all night. Heard Curtin & Brough were elected.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1863.
Drew a shelter tent & Jones drew one & we put up a good tent. Capt Osborne had an attack of the erysyplis, but still stays with the Brigade
FRIDAY 23
As Capt Osborne is too unwell Capt Johnson inspected the 143 Regt. I went along until his clerk came. Wrote out the report of the 149 & 150th Regts.
SATURDAY 24
Our brig was rear guard of Corps. Rained all day. Marched at daylight through the Gap: the old road to Gainsville from there to Bristow Station. Very muddy had to wade Brown Run just before getting here: 2 1/2 feet of water. Reb cavalry attacked men? of 2d. corps at Gainsville just after we passed drew up & expected a fight. I wished for one.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1863.
Were wakened at 2 AM, & marched at 6. Got quite wet before starting. Marched on the Warrenton pike through Gainsville &c Halted at Haymarket. The cavalry drove the reb av before us. About dark the cavalry fell back on us have been rather roughly handled. They captured some of our pickets & our div fell back in line until the 1st. & 2d. & rebs following, lost 2 killed & a few wounded & unclear
TUESDAY 20
No rebs in sight, marched about 3 PM? arriving at the mountain at dark our Brig in front of the corps. advanced very carefully through the Gap and drove up on this side, no fires alowed, very cold night
WEDNESDAY 21
No rebs to be found. they are said to have fallen back to the Rappahannock. Moved camp 300 yds. This is a fine hilly county like Washington Co. We passed within a mile of this place when coming from Pennsylvania.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1863.
Barclay came back to the Company. John & Parsons came back when we were at Centerville & took command about a week ago. Tobacco has become so scarce that navy sells for $3.50 & $4.00 per plug.
THURSDAY 29
A few sutlers came today, got a ration of soft bread the first for a month. Still lying at Bristoe Station: The Rebs destroyed the R.R. pretty effectually, burning bridges, ties &c.
FRIDAY 30
The 143d. Regiment has been sent to Manasses Junction to guard.

SUNDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1863.
Got into camp about midnight. Slept till morning & dryed our feet & clothes. Are camped in a beautiful ceader wood near where the battle was fought a week ago, a good many rebs are buried around here.
MONDAY 26
Col. Wister shot a wild turkey while eating dinner, it alighted on a small tree over their heads. Our Regt has been filled up with conscripts: recd 230 of them on Saturday
TUESDAY 27
Were wakened up last night expecting to march, the rebs were reported as advancing from Bealeton. Our Co recd 30 conscripts filling it up to the maximum

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1863.
The 143d. has been reinforced by the 149th.
WEDNESDAY 4
Nothing new.
THURSDAY 5
First and Second divisions marched this evening, and the word is that we move at daylight
1st. Brigade also went

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1863.
Nothing of importance.
SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 1
Attended church at the 150th.
MONDAY 2
All quiet

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1863.
Snowed a little today
TUESDAY 10
Very windy & cold, making it very unpleasant living in shelter tents.
WEDNESDAY 11
A lady came in in an ox cart to sell chickens, butter, eggs &c. She asked $1.00 a pound for butter and other things in proportion. She wanted to buy from our commissary

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1863.
Marched at daylight arriving at Warrenton Junction about 2 P.M. Our Brigade is to guard this post. The 1st around Kettle Run & the 3d. Manasses Junction
SATURDAY 7
Saw Genl Meade & staff. A grand move of the army of the Potomac this morning. Saw Co G 140th Cannonading commenced at 3 P.M. drove rebs across the Rappahannock capturing 1800 & 11 pieces of artillery. This was a brilliant movement.
SUNDAY 8
Was at church in 149th Mr Chandler of Vt preached. Saw the prisoners & some of the cannon captured yesterday. The N.C. troops are very tired of the war, & say they are willing to come back into the Union.

SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1863.
Attended preaching at the 149th
Text Luke 1st & 18th
Heard heavy firing towards Racoon Ford: have orders to be ready to move at short notice
MONDAY 16
Saw Robert Wilson of Co D 10th Reserves.
TUESDAY 17
Had inspection in the 149th & 150th Regiments. I think the army will soon make a move. I think we might whip the rebs now if reports of their strength are true.

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1863.
Nothing new.
FRIDAY 13
Ditto
SATURDAY 14
The picket saw some persons moving around outside the lines, & fired. Col. Wister had us all up under arms: the regiments also were up.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1863.
The 150th were paid today. It has been raining all day.
SUNDAY 22
Attended preaching at the 149th Regt. Received marching orders at 5 PM and marched at 7 arriving at Bristoe Station at 2 A.M. 150 Stayed behind & 143D went on to Manasses Junction a fine moonlight night.
MONDAY 23
Relieved the Md Brig. who went to Rappahannock Station. We appropriate their quarters which are splendid log huts. I have one 8 by 12 fitted up in fine style. I also found a kitten in one of the tents.

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1863.
As the pickets are relieved to day could not have inspection in the 143d.
THURSDAY 19
Had inspection in 143d. The Paymaster came this evening & paid part of our regiment. This is the day for the dedication of the Gettysburg cemetry
FRIDAY 20
The rest of our regiment and the 143d. were paid today. An old lady came in riding in an ox cart to sell chickens &c although these people have sugar?

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1863.
Heavy cannonading almost all day. Trains have almost all stoped running on this road I think it will soon be abandoned.
SATURDAY 28
Cannonading today. The Cavalry captured another guerilla. They went out to 4 miles on other side of Thoroughfare Gap & found Mosely's Hd Qrs. He was away. They brought in horses, cattle & 130 sheep and any number of turkies & chickens
SUNDAY 29
While some of them were out after wood today 40 guerillas attacked them & captured 2 of them. Some 60 more of the cavalry went out and chased them 10 miles but could not capture any.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1863.
There are a great many women who come in to sell things such as turkies, butter, egg, pies &c. The 4th Pa Cav came here & reported to Col. Wister
WEDNESDAY 25
Bought a turkey for $2.00. Tate went home early this morning on a 10 day furlough. Lieut Dalgliesh * some cavalry captured a guerilla, a lieut of 1st N.C Cavalry.
THURSDAY 26
This is thanksgiving day and the people & nation have cause for giving thanks. Col. Wister gave us at Hd Qrs a dinner. The cavalry captured two more guerillas. Heard cannonading this morning.

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1863.
The Col. received a rumor that caused him to think we would be relieved by the 5th corps. I hope not unless the army us going to make a bold push for Richmond sometime soon.
FRIDAY 4
The Penn.a. Reserves came about 5 P.M. so that settles the question of whether we are going to be relieved or not. Went down and saw all the boys. Black & McCahan came up after dark.
SATURDAY 5
Were relieved by 1st Brig of Res and marched at 3 P.M. Jones & I jumped on the cars & rode to Warrenton Junction. Slept in 150th old quarters without using anything of the Brigade.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1863.
Cannonading heard. Only one train daily runs now. We are unable to get any papers.
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1
All quiet in front. I dont know what is up. Three or four trains ran down today.
WEDNESDAY 2
Got papers today. They received a telegram at Hd Qrs stating that the army was all o this side of the Rapidan, near Brandy Station

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1863.
Have a pretty good hut finished except the chimney Col Wister was put under arrest for not hindering the men from tearing down some buildings.
THURSDAY 10
Built a chimney for my house. It draws pretty well
FRIDAY 11
Nothing new

SUNDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1863.
The 3d. Brig of Res. came here last night from Manasses & I saw all the boys again. Our Brig stayed at Catletts? & pass here before daylight walked to Rappahannock & then got on car to Brandy, got to camp again late?
MONDAY 7
Foudn the Brigade last night after asking at least 50 persons in a pine wood. The other Brigades went into splendid barracks erected by the Rebs for winter quarters.
TUESDAY 8
Commenced building a house although there have no orders? been given to build quarters it is astonishing how active all are working to make themselves comfortable.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1863.
Had an inspection in the 149th Regt today. This Regt. are said to have the best quarters in the Corps. They went into a perfect forest and now have a city, all done with their axes.
WEDNESDAY 16
Had an inspection in the 143d. Regt. The capt. recd an order to seize all axes & turn them in to the Div Q.M wishing thereby to recover 350 that have been purloined from Corps Hd Qrs.
THURSDAY 17
Rained all day and therefore the inspection of the 150th Regt was postponed. I put in my application for a 10 day furlough.

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1863.
The weather continues fine for this time of year, but winter campaigning in this country is impossible.
SUNDAY 13
Attended divine services at the 150th Regt.
MONDAY 14
Easton & Cubbage went home this morning on 10 day furloughs

MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1863.
Nothing yet from my furlough I almost wish it would not come approved now as it would not suit me to go now as well as sometime again.
TUESDAY 22
Nothing new
WEDNESDAY 23
Received orders to be ready to move at a moments notice. It is too bad to think of leaving our good quarters at this time of year.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1863.
There was something wrong in my furlough, corrected it and sent it up to Division it went from there to Corps Hd Quarters immediately.
SATURDAY 19
Had inspection in the 150th Regt. I am looking for my furlough to come back, so Capt. Osborne can go home after I come back and be there again New Years
SUNDAY 20
Quite cold today. No news yet of any furlough

SUNDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1863.
Commenced raining last night and continued all day. The troops were moved a short distance and ordered to build quarters.
MONDAY 28
Ours & the 1st Brigade were consolidated under the name of the 1st Brig. Col Wister commanding, all our staff remaining, also Lt Funk as AADG
TUESDAY 29
Nothing new

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1863.
Moved at daylight. Marched to Culpepper by way of Brandy Station. The Div camped just outside town. Col Wister took up his quarters in a house in town & we in a small out house
FRIDAY 25
Culpepper is about the same kind of a town as Warrenton. There is a cooking stove and utensils in our house. We had waffles for our Christmas dinner.
SATURDAY 26
The troops have not recd orders to build quarters. they are lying around, in their shelter tents suffering greatly from cold.

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1863.
Lts SLagle & Dalgliesh received leaves of absence and started for home.
THURSDAY 31
Moved Hd Qrs to house where 1st Brig Hd Qrs were. Mrs Green lives here. She has quite an old homestead and some slaves, who are unwilling to leave her. The year closed with me at Culpeper Va. Last closed with me at Washington, where will the next find me? I hope at home, the country enjoying peace.
